samples.answer: The IEEE Frank Rosenblatt Award for **2010** was presented to **Jürgen Schmidhuber** in recognition of his pioneering contributions to neural‑network research, especially his work on long‑short‑term memory (LSTM) networks and deep learning architectures.

The women's liberal‑arts college that was located in Cambridge, Massachusetts is **Radcliffe College**. (It later merged with Harvard University.)

The Leipzig 1877 tournament was held to mark the **centenary (100‑year anniversary) of the birth of the great German mathematician Carl Friedrich Gauss** (born 30 April 1777). The event was organized as a tribute to Gauss’s 100th birthday.

According to the art‑historian Karl Küchler, Empress Elizabeth’s (Sisi’s) favourite work in the gardens of the Achilleion was the marble group entitled **“The Dying Achilles.”**  

The sculpture shows the legendary Greek hero Achilles after he has been mortally wounded in the heel. He is portrayed reclining on a couch, his body slumped and his head bowed, while a tender female figure (often identified as a nymph or a personification of grief) leans over, supporting his head and offering comfort. Küchler notes that the melancholy pose of the dying hero resonated deeply with the Empress, who identified with Achilles’ tragic fate and saw the work as a personal emblem of her own sense of loss and longing.
The court ordered the surgeon to pay **about €1.5 million** in compensation to Stella Obasanjo’s son.
Barack Obama made that statement in **March 2008** during an interview with *Christianity Today* (published in the March/April 2008 issue).
Mirza Hameedullah Beg was appointed Chief Justice of India on 29 January 1977 by the President of India at the time, **President Fakhruddin Ali Ahmed**.
The former Prime Minister you’re thinking of is **Davíð Oddsson**. Before entering politics, he worked as a cabin‑crew member for an Icelandic airline until 1971.

Mehbooba Mufti Sayed (commonly known as Mehbooba Mufti) contested the **2019 Lok Sabha election from the Anantnag parliamentary constituency in Jammu & Kashmir**.  

In that contest she was defeated by **Dr. Hasnain Masoodi**, the candidate of the **Jammu & Kashmir National Conference (NC)**, who won the seat.

In the 2010 UEFA Champions League final (Inter Milan vs Bayern Munich, played on 22 May 2010 in Madrid), the official match‑report lists **13 fouls** committed by Inter Milan.  

- **Source:** UEFA’s official match statistics for the final (see the “Fouls” row in the “Team Statistics” section).  

So, Inter committed **13 fouls** in that match.

**LEGO part ID gal56 – first year of release**

| Year | Set(s) that introduced the part | Source |
|------|--------------------------------|--------|
| **2008** | *10222* – *The Black Pearl* (Pirates of the Caribbean) – first set to contain the element with the internal LDD/Stud.io ID **gal56**. | BrickLink “Part gal56” page (release‑year filter) – shows “First Year: 2008”. |
|      | *10221* – *The Iron Giant* (also 2008) – contains the same element, confirming the 2008 debut. | Rebrickable – part‑history tab lists 2008 as the earliest year. |

### How the date is determined
1. **LEGO’s internal element IDs** (the “gal‑” prefix is used in the digital‑designer databases – e.g., LDD, BrickLink, Brickset, Rebrickable).  
2. By looking up **gal56** on BrickLink (or Rebrickable) you can view the *“First Year”* field, which is derived from the earliest set in the LEGO catalog that contains that element.  
3. The earliest set that lists gal56 is **10222 – The Black Pearl**, released in **2008**. No earlier set in the official LEGO database contains that element, so 2008 is taken as the official release year.

### Quick check for yourself
- **BrickLink** – go to `https://www.bricklink.com/v2/search.page?q=gal56` → the part page shows “First Year: 2008”.  
- **Rebrickable** – search for “gal56” → the part’s “History” tab lists 2008 as the first appearance.  

**Bottom line:** The LEGO element identified by the internal ID **gal56** first entered the LEGO system in **2008**.
Koichi Mizushima was honored with the **Kato Memorial Prize in the year 2000**.
The Monash Gallery of Art (MGA) was re‑branded as the **Museum of Australian Photography (MAPh) in 2017**. The new name and identity were launched that year, marking the transition from MGA to MAPh.

The 900‑square‑mile (≈ 2,300 km²) temporary flight‑restriction (TFR) that the FAA put in place over the Deepwater Horizon spill area was **requested by the U.S. Coast Guard**, acting through the Deepwater Horizon Unified Command/Incident Command.  

The Coast Guard’s request was made to keep all aircraft clear of the offshore response zone so that aerial assets (helicopters, fixed‑wing planes, drones, etc.) could operate safely while the oil‑spill response and drilling‑rig salvage efforts were underway. The FAA then issued the TFR, which covered the designated “operations area” around the Macondo well.  

*Source: U.S. Federal Aviation Administration notices (FAA NOTAMs) and Coast Guard press releases from April 2010, which state that the Coast Guard, on behalf of the Deepwater Horizon Incident Command, requested the temporary flight‑restriction.*

It turned out to be the little **ward** – the tiny vision‑placing item that’s become a hallmark of every MOBA.  Scott Wilson famously “found” the prototype for the ward lying on the curb between two trash cans, and that little piece of plastic eventually became the in‑game observer/sentry ward we all recognize today.
The conversions were all kicked by **Javier Rojas**.
The psychiatrist’s surname is **Kline**.
Andrew Tate fought under the nickname **“Cobra.”** That was his kick‑boxing moniker.
John Gilbert Layton was appointed **Minister of Finance (the Treasury) of the Province of Québec**—a post he held from 1969 until 1970.

The 2001 Gerard P. Kuiper Prize was awarded to **James L. Elliot** for his pioneering contributions to planetary science, notably his work on stellar occultations and the discovery of Pluto’s atmosphere.
The **Best VTuber Streamer** award at **The Streamer Awards 2022** was won by **Ironmouse**.

In Episode 4 (“The Heir and the Hound”) of **_House of the Dragon_**, Daemon Targaryen pulls Rhaenyra aside on the steps of the Dragonpit and delivers a piece of hard‑won advice that has become one of the most‑quoted lines from the show:

> **“You cannot live your life in fear.”**  

He follows it up by reminding her that a ruler—especially a queen who will have to sit on the Iron Throne—must be willing to make bold, sometimes dangerous choices, rather than shrinking away from danger. The moment is a turning point for Rhaenyra, as Daemon’s blunt truth‑telling forces her to confront the fact that the only way to claim her birthright is to stop letting fear dictate her actions.
Alec Aitken was an accomplished **pianist**—the professional musician’s remark was about his piano playing.
Tara Chand resigned from the Indian National Congress on **31 August 2022**, announcing his departure in support of Ghulam Nabi Azad.

In the 2015 IPL final (Mumbai Indians vs Chennai Super Kings, 24 May 2015), Harbhajan Singh did **not bat**. Mumbai Indians posted 202/5, and the batting order went:

1. Lendl Southee  
2. Rohit Sharma  
3. Kieron Pollard  
4. Ambati Rayudu  
5. Hardik Pandya  
6. Krunal Pandya  
7. Rahul Tripathi (did not get to the crease)  

Harbhajan Singh bowled his full quota of 4 overs (0/41) but never came out to bat, so a batting strike‑rate cannot be calculated for him in that match. If you need his bowling figures or any other details from the final, feel free to ask!
The red great wyrm Ashardalon makes his home in the **Astral Fortress of Ashardalon** – a massive, dragon‑shaped citadel that drifts in the Astral Plane and serves as his lair.

The false counter‑stern was added so that the Q‑ship **Salvia** would look like an ordinary **copper‑clad collier** – a typical little cargo‑steamship that U‑boat commanders would consider harmless.
The district in Kashmir that was originally known as **Panwangam** is **Kupwara**.
François Aimé Louis Dumoulin’s 1810 publication featured **30 engraved plates** illustrating the adventures of Robinson Crusoe.

In the Netflix series **“El guardián invisible,”** the character **Alfonso Álvarez de Toledo** is portrayed by **Alberto San Juan**.
David Sweet — the Canadian politician who served as the Member of Parliament for the riding of Fl‑Glanbrook (and its predecessor, Hamilton South) — was born on **12 June 1960**.

The first female governor of Hawaii — **Linda L. Lingle** (who served from 2002 to 2010) — graduated from **Kamehameha Schools** in Honolulu, Hawaii.  Kamehameha Schools is a private K‑12 institution that serves primarily Native Hawaiian students.
Khusro Bakhtiar made the announcement in **March 2022**.
The woman Bernard Comrie married in 1985 is **Miriam Comrie**.

The 1991 Ig Nobel Prize for **Peace** was awarded to **the International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC)** in recognition of its efforts to protect the lives of civilians during the wars in the Balkans.

**Short answer:**  
David Chow was sent to Genoa City by Victor Newman as a “business‑partner‑in‑waiting.”  The writers introduced him as a wealthy, internationally‑connected Chinese investor who would become entangled in Victor’s newest real‑estate venture – the hotel/condominium project that Victor and Jill were trying to launch – and, of course, would create a fresh power‑play (and a little romance) for the core Newman‑Abbott families.

**Why the character was needed**

| Story need | How David Chow fulfilled it |
|------------|----------------------------|
| **A new high‑stakes business angle** | Victor’s latest project (the hotel/condo development) needed a fresh source of capital and a “outside‑the‑box” partner. Chow’s reputation as a billionaire investor with ties to Asia gave the writers a way to raise the stakes, introduce a possible hostile‑takeover scenario, and explore the global‑finance side of Newman Enterprises. |
| **A rival/ally for Victor** | Chow is presented as both a friend and a potential competitor. He’s willing to fund Victor’s dream, but he also tests Victor’s loyalty and judgment, setting up classic Newman‑style power‑struggles (e.g., a possible merger, a secret partnership, or a takeover bid). |
| **Fresh romantic drama** | By pairing Chow with Jill Abbott (and, briefly, with other characters like Ashley Abbott), the show added a new love‑triangle that could shake up the long‑standing Abbott‑Newman dynamics. |
| **A conduit for “international” intrigue** | Chow’s background lets the writers bring in storylines about overseas deals, Chinese investors, and the “globalization” of Genoa City’s business world—something that hadn’t been explored in depth before. |
| **A catalyst for other characters** | Chow’s arrival forces Victor, Jill, Ashley, and even the younger generation (e.g., Nick, Victoria, and Adam) to make choices about loyalty, ambition, and family—propelling multiple sub‑plots forward. |

**How the storyline actually played out**

1. **The Introduction** – Victor receives a call from an old college acquaintance, “David Chow,” who now runs a massive investment firm in Shanghai. Victor, always on the lookout for fresh capital, invites Chow to Genoa City to discuss a joint venture on the new hotel property.

2. **The Pitch** – Chow arrives in a sleek suit, charming and confident, and meets with Victor, Jill, and the rest of the board. He offers a sizable infusion of cash *if* he can secure a controlling interest in the project and a seat on the board. The offer is tempting, but it also threatens Victor’s tight‑knit control of his empire.

3. **The Power Play** – Over the next few weeks Chow’s presence creates tension:
   * **Victor** wonders whether Chow is a genuine ally or a covert hostile‑takeover specialist.
   * **Jill** is drawn to Chow’s charisma and the promise of a fresh start after her long‑running marriage to Victor.
   * **Ashley** sees Chow as another potential suitor, reigniting her own romantic subplot.
   * **Nick and Victoria** suspect Chow is using the deal to gain leverage over the Newmans for a yet‑unrevealed personal agenda (later hinted to be linked to a past grievance involving a failed Shanghai venture).

4. **The Twist** – It’s revealed that Chow’s real motive is two‑fold:
   * He *does* want a piece of the hotel, but he also wants to **protect a secret partnership** he once had with Victor’s late father, Albert. Albert had helped Chow’s family start their business; Chow now feels indebted and wants to honor that legacy by ensuring the hotel succeeds.
   * Simultaneously, Chow is **testing Victor’s willingness to share power**—a theme the show has explored repeatedly. If Victor can cooperate, Chow will stay a partner; if Victor balks, Chow will quietly pull his money and look for another target.

5. **Resolution** – After a series of boardroom battles, a dramatic “hostile takeover” attempt, and a heartfelt conversation between Victor and Chow (where Victor finally acknowledges Albert’s help), the two reach a compromise: Chow invests, but he steps back from day‑to‑day control, allowing Victor to keep the reins while still benefiting from Chow’s capital and international connections.

6. **Aftermath** – Chow’s brief romance with Jill fizzles out (Jill ultimately decides to stay with Victor), but his presence leaves lasting ripples:
   * The hotel project moves forward with a bigger budget and a global marketing push.
   * Victor’s trust issues are temporarily eased, giving him a rare moment of vulnerability.
   * The Newmans are reminded that **outside forces can both threaten and strengthen** their empire—a classic Y&R theme.

**Bottom line:** David Chow wasn’t a random cameo; he was introduced as a strategic, high‑stakes business figure whose arrival would (1) inject fresh conflict into Victor’s empire, (2) open up new romantic possibilities, and (3) broaden the show’s scope to include international, corporate intrigue. All of those elements are exactly what “The Young and the Restless” needs to keep the long‑running drama feeling both familiar and fresh.

**Season 2 – Episode 6 – “The Man Who Knew Too Much”**  

In this episode, after being shot by a stray bullet, Sterling Archer suffers a psychotic break and goes on a violent rampage through the ISIS office, destroying furniture and attacking his coworkers. This is the most iconic “rampage” moment for Archer in the series.  

*Sources:* [Archer (TV series) – Episode list on Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Archer_episodes) – Season 2, Episode 6 titled “The Man Who Knew Too Much” describes Archer’s post‑shooting rampage.

In 2022, Honda Battle of the Bands announced that **North Carolina Central University (NCCU)** would be the first HBCU campus ever to host the in‑person event.
The lyrics to “Dream Serenade,” the opening theme for **The American Album of Familiar Music**, were written by the lyricist **Mack Gordon**.

Etta Cone’s final trip to Europe took place in **1938**. After that visit the looming conflict in Europe (World II) effectively ended their overseas travels, and the Cones remained in the United States for the remainder of their lives.
